Title: Water too pricey for some California almond growers
Description:
A San Joaquin Valley almond grower in Fresno County was using “deficit irrigation,” giving trees less water than they need because he doesn’t have enough water.  He also left a third of his land unplanted to leave water for the almonds.  He was also considering pulling out 100 of his 600 acres of almond trees after the harvest.
California produces 80% of the world’s almonds and has a $6 billion almond industry, but the lack of water is forcing almond growers to make hard decisions about whether to continue growing them as some almond orchards were planted in areas with unreliable water supplies.  Numerous growers could not afford the water and have allowed the trees to die.
Associated Press News (New York), Aug 17, 2021

Title: Grape crop lighter for some growers in Sonoma County, California
Description:
The harvest of grapes for sparkling wines began in Sonoma County, but the grapes for still wines will stay on the vines for a few more weeks.  The crop was lighter and berries smaller for the most part, but grape growers are hopeful for the quality of the grapes despite the drought.  Many growers were using less far water this year than in previous years.
Sonoma Index-Tribune (Calif.), Aug 19, 2021

Title: Drought stressed almond trees in the San Joaquin Valley, California
Description:
After a dry spring and hot summer, almond trees in the San Joaquin Valley are beginning to be stressed.  With irrigation and water quality issues, many growers are worried about the next season and wonder what the lack of water has done to the trees.
ABC 30 Action News (Fresno, Calif.), Aug 12, 2021

Title: Drought affecting grapes in Sonoma County, California
Description:
Some wine grapes in the Napa and Sonoma Valleys were struggling amid the intense drought and were stressed with the backs of the leaves showing.  The fruit and leaf canopies are smaller this year.  One vineyard's well went dry.
KPIX-TV CBS 5 San Francisco (Calif.), Aug 10, 2021

Title: High demand for dowser in Napa County, California
Description:
As drought persists and farmers are desperate to find water, a Sonoma County dowser was scheduled for three to four weeks in advance and was working Saturdays, too.
KPIX-TV CBS 5 San Francisco (Calif.), Aug 9, 2021

Title: Reduced withdrawals from Russian River in California to keep Lake Mendocino higher
Description:
Lake Mendocino dropped to its second lowest level since the reservoir was built with the rainy season months away yet.  The lake held a little over 24,000 acre-feet of water, but has only dropped below 25,000 acre-feet three times.   
State and local water managers have been reducing withdrawals from the Russian River to slow releases from Lake Mendocino in an effort to make sure that the level does not fall below 20,000 acre feet before Oct. 1, in case next winter is dry.
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), Aug 5, 2021

Title: Less power being generated at Lake Shasta in California over the summer
Description:
Drought is depleting rivers and reservoirs used for hydropower production in California and elsewhere, causing the largest disruptions to hydropower generation in decades and sometimes forcing a return to dirty fossil fuels for immediate power.
Power generation at Lake Shasta was about 30% less than usual this summer, according to a team leader for the Bureau of Reclamation's operations.  The dam usually generates about 710 MW during the summer, but in July was making only 500 MW.
Reuters (New York), Aug 13, 2021

Title: Creeks drying, fish dying in Santa Clara County, California
Description:
With rain lacking for more than two years in Santa Clara County, creeks and fish were suffering as a result.  The Los Gatos Creek was so low that fish have died because the Santa Clara Valley Water District does not have enough water to release to support the fish.
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), Aug 2, 2021

Title: Water being released through base of dam at Lake Oroville in Butte County, California to maintain river temperature requirement
Description:
Lake Oroville dropped to its lowest level since September 1977 and was below 643.5 feet above sea level on the morning of Aug. 3.  The Edward Hyatt Power Plant is expected to lose the ability to produce power due to low water levels in early August.
Water has been released through the base of the dam to maintain river temperature requirements in the Feather River below the dam.  
Oroville Mercury-Register (Calif.), Aug 3, 2021

Title: California farmers in Sacramento, San Joaquin river basins to lose access to rivers, streams for irrigation
Description:
California state regulators chose to end farmers’ water diversions from the Sacramento and San Joaquin river basins to protect the river waters for drinking and endangered fish.  Farmers were already getting little to no water from state and federal projects as snowpack was low and runoff was less than expected.  The emergency curtailment will take effect in about two weeks.
Such a broad action as this was not done during the previous drought.
The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug 3, 2021

Title: California farmers in Sacramento, San Joaquin river basins to lose access to rivers, streams for irrigation
Description:
California state regulators chose to end farmers’ water diversions from the Sacramento and San Joaquin river basins to protect the river waters for drinking and endangered fish.  Farmers were already getting little to no water from state and federal projects as snowpack was low and runoff was less than expected.  The emergency curtailment will take effect in about two weeks.
Such a broad action as this was not done during the previous drought.
The Fresno Bee (Calif.), Aug 3, 2021

Title: California rescue operations, other resources  help people care for pets amid drought
Description:
With no pasture and water supplies running dry, some Sonoma County animal owners were making the heartrending decision to give up their animals because they no longer have water.  Resources do exist to help animal owners provide water if they run out so animals can stay with their owners.
KPIX-TV CBS 5 San Francisco (Calif.), Aug 4, 2021

Title: $15 million in drought relief for Klamath Basin in Oregon, California
Description:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced $15 million in drought relief for Klamath Basin growers who agree to reduce their irrigation demand so the water can be used for other purposes.  The Bureau of Reclamation also has a $15 million program for the basin, but the Klamath Water Users Association says more financial assistance is still needed.
KDRV-TV ABC 12 (Medford, Ore.), Aug 2, 2021

Title: $15 million in drought relief for Klamath Basin in Oregon, California
Description:
The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced $15 million in drought relief for Klamath Basin growers who agree to reduce their irrigation demand so the water can be used for other purposes.  The Bureau of Reclamation also has a $15 million program for the basin, but the Klamath Water Users Association says more financial assistance is still needed.
KDRV-TV ABC 12 (Medford, Ore.), Aug 2, 2021

Title: Excellent river rafting in California, despite drought
Description:
The rafting on the Tuolumne and American rivers looks to be fantastic for the rest of the summer, marking the best season in decades.  The San Francisco Public Utilities Commission plans its flow regime and releases to maximize rafting opportunities on the Tuolumne River.  Flows are arranged similarly on the American River to support rafting.  Rafting should be good at least through Labor Day weekend.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), July 29, 2021

Title: Numerous small towns in northern California dangerously low on water
Description:
Many small towns in northern California were facing water shortages with more than 130,000 people affected.  Some towns have reported that they were in danger of running out or were dealing with extreme shortages.  Water is also needed for firefighting, further stressing dwindling supplies.
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), July 30, 2021

Many small towns in northern California were facing water shortages with more than 130,000 people affected.  Some towns have reported that they were in danger of running out or were dealing with extreme shortages.  Water is also needed for firefighting, further stressing dwindling supplies.
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), July 30, 2021

Title: California ranchers liquidate herds
Description:
California’s dairy farmers and beef-cattle producers were struggling to find feed for their livestock, but it is so expensive, that even if feed can even be found, profits on the livestock were dwindling, leading to cattle liquidation.
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 29, 2021

Title: Uptick in cockroach infestations in Placer, Sacramento counties in California
Description:
Heat and drought were stressing cockroaches, leading to more infestations in South Placer County towns to Sacramento.  Those in the pest control industry saw this trend begin months ago with new clients needing help with the insects.  Urban areas seem to be harder hit than rural locales.
One Granite Bay resident noted that his backyard appeared as if it were moving at night from all of the “creepy crawlies.”  
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 26, 2021

Title: Uptick in cockroach infestations in Placer, Sacramento counties in California
Description:

The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 26, 2021

Title: Gold Rush town ruins visible in Folsom Lake, California
Description:
Folsom Lake has become so low that ruins of Gold Rush towns were again visible.  Remnants of Salmon Falls, Red Banks and Mormon Island were on dry land, revealing more artifacts by the day as the water continued to recede.
Los Angeles Times (Calif.), July 27, 2021

Title: Power production 20% of capacity at Lake Oroville in California
Description:
Lake Oroville’s Edward Hyatt Power plant may lose the ability to generate hydropower in August or September, but was able to remain online during the droughts of 1977 and 2014-15.  
California’s hydropower generating capacity has dropped by about 1,000 megawatts, due to drought, per the California Public Utilities Commission.
Los Angeles Times, July 21, 2021

The Edward Hyatt Power Plant at Lake Oroville likely has enough water to continue producing hydropower for another two to three months before the water level is expected to fall too low for further power production, according to a California Energy Commission spokesperson.  The hydroelectric power plant, the fourth largest energy producer in California, has never closed before since it began operation in 1967, but its production was 20% of total capacity as water levels fall.  The present water level was near 700 feet above sea level, but power generation would end at 640 feet. 
CNN (Atlanta, Ga.), June 17, 2021

Title: Emergency curtailment order in the works, affecting Sacramento, San Joaquin river basins in California
Description:
The State Water Resources Control Board released an “emergency curtailment” order that would deprive thousands of farmers of the use of rivers and streams in the Sacramento and San Joaquin river watersheds.  Exceptions will be made for drinking water and other human needs.  The action was taken to protect drinking water and endangered fish.  A board will vote on the order on Aug. 3, and the order could take effect about two weeks after that, or around Aug. 17.  
Even during California’s last drought, regulators did not cut farmers off like this.
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), July 23, 2021

Title: Fishing guide operations suspended in Kern County, California
Description:
A Kernville fly fishing school and guide service were suspending guide operations due to high water temperatures that can be lethal to the fish.  California Fish and Wildlife stopped stocking the Kern River with fish, due to warm waters. 
KMPH FOX26News (Fresno, Calif.), July 13, 2021

Title: Remains of Mormon Island seen in Folsom Lake, California
Description:
The waters of Folsom Lake receded low enough to reveal Mormon Island, a Gold Rush village, settled in the 1840s by prospectors.  Some of the exposed remnants were building foundations, bricks, broken pottery and rusty nails.  The town was flooded in 1955 when Folsom Dam was constructed and was most recently visible in September 2015 during drought.  
KRON4 (San Francisco), July 13, 2021

Title: Only two boat ramps open at Lake Oroville in California
Description:
Just two boat ramps were open at Lake Oroville as the water level continued to fall to 667 feet of elevation on July 14.  
KCRA-TV NBC 3 Sacramento (Calif.), July 14, 2021

Title: Almond production down 13% in California's Central Valley due to limited water, heat
Description:
In May, the U.S. Department of Agriculture forecasted an almond harvest of a record 3.2 billion pounds, but drought led to a 13% reduction with an expectation of about 2.8 billion pounds from the August-October harvest.  Low water allocations of 80% and June extreme heat prevented the crop from developing as well as expected.  
California produces about 80% of the world’s almonds.  Despite the smaller harvest, this year’s crop will still be the second largest ever, second to the 2020 harvest of 3.12 billion pounds.
The Modesto Bee (Calif.), July 13, 2021

Title: 1.1 million hatchery salmon moved from Siskiyou County, California
Description:
The California Department of Fish and Wildlife moved 1.1 million juvenile, fall-run Chinook salmon from the Iron Gate Fish Hatchery in Siskiyou County, due to drought and warm, low flows in the Klamath River.  The fish were taken to the Trinity River Hatchery.
KRCR-TV ABC 7 (Redding, Calif.), July 15, 2021

Title: Water conservation of 10% requested in Contra Costa Water District in California
Description:
The Contra Costa Water District requests that customers voluntarily curb their water use by 10%.  The water has a slightly musty smell, due to increased salt and algae in the raw water, but the water is safe to drink.
KPIX-TV CBS 5 San Francisco (Calif.), July 8, 2021

Title: Outdoor watering once weekly in Marin County, California
Description:
The Marin Municipal Water District permits customers to use their sprinklers just one day weekly on an assigned day, with drip irrigation allowed twice weekly.  The rules were adopted because some individuals persisted in using sprinklers three or more times weekly.  
The district mandated a 40% collective reduction in water use, compared with 2018-2020, but conservation has only reached 21%.  A water pipeline across the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge could be needed as an emergency supply project to keep water flowing next summer if the coming winter is dry.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), July 7, 2021

Title: Poor grass growth, increased cattle sales in Kern County, California
Description:
Drought and poor grass growth led to increased cattle sales since March at the Western Stockman’s Market in McFarland.  Sales were up between a quarter and a third as feed costs were prohibitively high, even for alternative feed like almond hulls and cottonseed.  A number of ranchers were even considering ending the family ranching business, despite a 150-year history for some.  A Kern County rancher sold a third of his herd for lack of grass.
The Bakersfield Californian, July 5, 2021

Title: 1.1 million young salmon relocated, due to poor conditions in Klamath River in northern California
Description:
Drought and poor conditions in the Klamath River led the California Department of Fish and Wildlife to relocate 1.1 million young Chinook salmon.  The fish were at the Iron Gate, Fall Creek and Trinity River hatchery facilities until conditions improve.  The young salmon will likely be released in October or November, rather than this spring.
KOBI-TV NBC5 (Medford, Ore.), July 8, 2021

Title: 1.1 million young salmon relocated, due to poor conditions in Klamath River in northern California
Description:
Drought and poor conditions in the Klamath River led the California Department of Fish and Wildlife to relocate 1.1 million young Chinook salmon. Title: Vegetation at or below historically low levels in San Mateo and Santa Cruz counties in California
Description:
Measured vegetation moisture levels in San Mateo County were at or below historic low values for this time of year.  The Cal Fire San Mateo-Santa Cruz Unit tested vegetation at various sites in both counties on July 1 and found a significant decrease in water content. 
In 2020, it was early to mid-August before moisture levels fell this low, according to Cal Fire.
San Mateo, CA Patch, July 8, 2021

Title: Vegetation at or below historically low levels in San Mateo and Santa Cruz counties in California
Description:
Measured vegetation moisture levels in San Mateo County were at or below historic low values for this time of year.  The Cal Fire San Mateo-Santa Cruz Unit tested vegetation at various sites in both counties on July 1 and found a significant decrease in water content. 
In 2020, it was early to mid-August before moisture levels fell this low, according to Cal Fire.
San Mateo, CA Patch, July 8, 2021

Title: Northern California farmers relying on groundwater
Description:
Northern California farmers who typically get water from lakes, rivers and streams were limited on how much they can use, and, instead, were forced to leave fields fallow or pump groundwater.  Farmers were not getting any water from the state or federal projects.
Chico Enterprise Record (Calif.), July 4, 2021

Title: Drought emergency in 50 counties in California
Description:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom included another nine counties in the emergency drought proclamation that encompasses 50 of the state's 58 counties.  The nine counties were Inyo, Marin, Mono, Monterey, San Luis Obispo, San Mateo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara and Santa Cruz.
Associated Press News (New York), July 8, 2021

California Gov. Gavin Newsom included another 39 counties in his drought emergency declaration, which originally included only Sonoma and Mendocino counties. No mandatory drought water conservation targets were ordered, as was done during the previous drought, because Californians were using 16% less water than they did in 2013 as conservation had become a habit.
Newsom will also request $5.1 billion over the next four years, including $1 billion to help low-income residents pay overdue water bills, $1.3 billion for upgrades to drinking water systems and funds for groundwater projects, canal repairs and fish restoration projects.
Warm temperatures melted the Sierra Nevada snowpack quickly, which was only 59% of historical average on April 1.  Much of the runoff soaked into the dry soil rather than refilling reservoirs, which consequently hold 500,000 acre-feet less than was anticipated, enough water for 1 million households.  
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), May 10, 2021

Gov. Gavin Newsom declared drought emergency in Mendocino and Sonoma counties as they deal with “substantial water supply and ecosystem challenges.”  State officials were directed to work with local water suppliers to conserve more water. 
Lake Mendocino was at about 43% capacity, and Lake Sonoma was about 62% full.
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), April 21, 2021

Title: Drought emergency in 50 counties in California
Description:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom included another nine counties in the emergency drought proclamation that encompasses 50 of the state's 58 counties.  The nine counties were Inyo, Marin, Mono, Monterey, San Luis Obispo, San Mateo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara and Santa Cruz.
Associated Press News (New York), July 8, 2021

California Gov. Gavin Newsom included another 39 counties in his drought emergency declaration, which originally included only Sonoma and Mendocino counties. No mandatory drought water conservation targets were ordered, as was done during the previous drought, because Californians were using 16% less water than they did in 2013 as conservation had become a habit.
Newsom will also request $5.1 billion over the next four years, including $1 billion to help low-income residents pay overdue water bills, $1.3 billion for upgrades to drinking water systems and funds for groundwater projects, canal repairs and fish restoration projects.
Warm temperatures melted the Sierra Nevada snowpack quickly, which was only 59% of historical average on April 1.  Much of the runoff soaked into the dry soil rather than refilling reservoirs, which consequently hold 500,000 acre-feet less than was anticipated, enough water for 1 million households.  
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), May 10, 2021

Gov. Gavin Newsom declared drought emergency in Mendocino and Sonoma counties as they deal with “substantial water supply and ecosystem challenges.”  State officials were directed to work with local water suppliers to conserve more water. 
Lake Mendocino was at about 43% capacity, and Lake Sonoma was about 62% full.
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), April 21, 2021

Title: Drought emergency in 50 counties in California
Description:
California Gov. Gavin Newsom included another nine counties in the emergency drought proclamation that encompasses 50 of the state's 58 counties.  The nine counties were Inyo, Marin, Mono, Monterey, San Luis Obispo, San Mateo, Santa Barbara, Santa Clara and Santa Cruz.
Associated Press News (New York), July 8, 2021

California Gov. Gavin Newsom included another 39 counties in his drought emergency declaration, which originally included only Sonoma and Mendocino counties. No mandatory drought water conservation targets were ordered, as was done during the previous drought, because Californians were using 16% less water than they did in 2013 as conservation had become a habit.
Newsom will also request $5.1 billion over the next four years, including $1 billion to help low-income residents pay overdue water bills, $1.3 billion for upgrades to drinking water systems and funds for groundwater projects, canal repairs and fish restoration projects.
Warm temperatures melted the Sierra Nevada snowpack quickly, which was only 59% of historical average on April 1.  Much of the runoff soaked into the dry soil rather than refilling reservoirs, which consequently hold 500,000 acre-feet less than was anticipated, enough water for 1 million households.  
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), May 10, 2021

Gov. Gavin Newsom declared drought emergency in Mendocino and Sonoma counties as they deal with “substantial water supply and ecosystem challenges.”  State officials were directed to work with local water suppliers to conserve more water. 
Lake Mendocino was at about 43% capacity, and Lake Sonoma was about 62% full.
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), April 21, 2021

Title: Water storage drying up quickly in Sonoma County, California
Description:
Sonoma County water storage was drying up much more quickly than during the last intense stretch of drought in 2014-2016.  Many livestock farmers were selling animals and thinning herds to cope with dry pastures and high feed prices.  Some farmers who use Russian River water will lose access to that water once area reservoirs fall below a certain level, forcing farmers to adjust.
Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), June 25, 20221

Title: Fallow land; expensive water in Fresno County, California
Description:
A Fresno County farmer left one-third of his 6,000 acres fallow because water was so scarce and relied upon emergency sources for a reduced crop.  The supplemental water cost him $2,000 per acre-foot, compared to normal water prices of $200 to $250 per acre-foot.
“If there is no water, there is no work, no money.”
Times of San Diego (Calif.), June 26, 2021

Title: Fire restrictions on BLM lands in northeast California, western Nevada
Description:
The Bureau of Land Management enacted fire restrictions on public lands managed by the Eagle Lake and Applegate field offices in Lassen, Modoc, Plumas, Sierra, Shasta and Siskiyou counties in California, and in Washoe County, Nevada.  The restrictions took effect on July 1 and will remain in effect until further notice.
Susanville Stuff (Calif.), July 1, 2021

Title: More water conservation needed from the public in Marin County, California
Description:
Marin City residents conserved about 19% recently, although conservation of 40% has been requested.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), June 19, 2021

Although the Marin Water District asked its customers to curb their water use by 40%, this past week water conservation amounted to 11%.  Water officials say that it takes time for people to adjust their behavior to the new conservation request.
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), June 4, 2021

Title: 45-day moratorium on ag well drilling in Glenn County, California
Description:
A 45-day moratorium on agricultural well drilling was unanimously approved in Glenn County as domestic wells went dry.  The Glenn County Board of Supervisors declared a local drought emergency on June 4 and also approved the creation of an ad hoc committee to address drought matters. 
KRCR-TV ABC 7 & KCVU-TV Fox 20 (Redding, Calif.), June 22, 2021

Title: Local drought emergency in Glenn County, California
Description:
The Glenn County Board of Supervisors declared a local drought emergency on June 4 and also approved the creation of an ad hoc committee to address drought matters. 
KRCR-TV ABC 7 & KCVU-TV Fox 20 (Redding, Calif.), June 22, 2021

Title: Local drought emergency in Santa Clara County, California
Description:
A local emergency was declared in Santa Clara County, due to extreme drought.  Residents and businesses in unincorporated parts of the county were urged to conserve water.  
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), June 25, 2021

Title: Voluntary water conservation urged in Healdsburg, California
Description:
Healdsburg residents were urged to voluntarily conserve water as precipitation was 40% of normal through Jan. 19.  Lake Mendocino was at 45.1% of its targeted water supply curve as of Feb. 16.
Healdsburg, in conjunction with Sonoma-Marin Saving Water Partnership, will be launching a social media campaign with tips on reducing water waste. Healdsburg residents will also receive a water conservation mailer with their next utility bill.
The Healdsburg Tribune (Calif.), Feb. 23, 2021

Title: Stricter fire restrictions at Lake Tahoe, California/Nevada
Description:
Drought and heat led to increased fire restrictions in the Lake Tahoe Basin through November.  Fire-related activities were prohibited at developed recreation sites and in the backcountry.
Reno Gazette Journal (Nev.), June 17, 2021

The North Tahoe and Meeks Bay Fire Protection Districts announced a suspension of all solid fuel fires, including wood campfires and charcoal grills, for the summer as the forest was unusually dry.  Campfires and charcoal barbecues were still permitted in designated fire pits in campgrounds.
“Timber vegetation [is] already at summer dryness levels, and above normal fire activity is projected in the Sierra and Tahoe regions this summer and likely into the fall,” according to the North Tahoe Fire Protection District fire chief.
SFGate (San Francisco, Calif.), June 3, 2021

All open burning and recreational fires were prohibited in the Lake Tahoe basin.  The Amador/El Dorado Unit of Cal Fire suspended burn permits on May 10 for the season and on May 24, the Nevada Yuba Placer Unit did the same, leading to full suspension of residential burn permits.  
Tahoe Daily Tribune (South Lake Tahoe, Calif.), May 29, 2021

Title: Reductions ordered on minimum instream flows, diversions from California's Russian River
Description:
The California State Water Resources Control Board ordered reductions on minimum instream flows and diversions from the Russian River.  The temporary order issued on June 14 decreases instream flow requirements from 85 cubic feet per second to 35 cfs.  The order also requires the Sonoma County Water Agency and its contractors to reduce diversions from the river by 20 percent from last year’s usage between July 1 and mid-December 2021.  The aim was to keep more water stored in Lake Sonoma, the main source of water for Sonoma and Marin county residents. 
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), June 15, 2021

Title: Hiking trail in Joshua Tree National Park in California closed to allow bighorn sheep access to spring
Description:
The 49 Palms Trail was closed to tourists to allow bighorn sheep peaceful access to a spring near the trail as extreme drought gripped the area.  The trail will reopen after summer monsoons bring enough water to provide more water sources for the sheep.
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), June 14, 2021

Title: Junior water rights holders in Northern California ordered to stop diverting
Description:
The State Water Resources Control Board issued a directive on June 15 telling about 4,300 junior water rights holders from Fresno County north to the Oregon border to stop diverting water.  Affected areas included the Russian River watershed and the Scott River watershed in Siskiyou County.  The directive will likely be broadened before summer ends. 
Western Farm Press (Minneapolis, Minn.), June 17, 2021

Title: California's Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta farmers warned of "impending water unavailability"
Description:
The State Water Resources Control Board sent notices to about 6,600 farmers in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta watershed with water rights, alerting the farmers of “impending water unavailability” until winter rains return.  State and federal projects were either delivering very little or no water this year.
“The 2021 water year for the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Basin is currently the driest since 1977,” according to the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation.
Associated Press (N.Y.), June 16, 2021

“The 2021 water year for the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Basin is currently the driest since 1977,” according to the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation.
Associated Press (N.Y.), June 16, 2021

Title: Water being hauled for tule elk in Marin County, California
Description:
The National Park Service was hauling water for tule elk at Point Reyes National Seashore as drought dried up natural sources after two unusually dry years.  Three water troughs will provide water for the tule elk and will hopefully prevent animal deaths as occurred during the previous drought.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), June 11, 2021

Title: Small plane wreck discovered in Folsom Lake, California
Description:
A small plane that crashed into Folsom Lake on New Year's Day in 1965 may have been discovered by technicians tested sonar technology in the lake as the water was unusually low at 37% of capacity, due to drought.  
The San Diego Union-Tribune (Calif.), June 14, 2021

Title: Small plane wreck discovered in Folsom Lake, California
Description:
A small plane that crashed into Folsom Lake on New Year's Day in 1965 may have been discovered by technicians tested sonar technology in the lake as the water was unusually low at 37% of capacity, due to drought.  
The San Diego Union-Tribune (Calif.), June 14, 2021

Title: Fruit, nut trees need more water, but have less in Sutter, Yuba counties in California
Description:
With the dry soil in northern California, fruit and nut trees were in need of more moisture than usual.  Growers were watering more, driving up costs for electricity, while businesses that service pumps were busy and had work scheduled for months.  The quality of fruits like peaches, plums and prunes is expected to be lower than usual.
FOX40 (Sacramento, Calif.), June 7, 2021

Title: Fruit, nut trees need more water, but have less in Sutter, Yuba counties in California
Description:
With the dry soil in northern California, fruit and nut trees were in need of more moisture than usual.  Growers were watering more, driving up costs for electricity, while businesses that service pumps were busy and had work scheduled for months.  The quality of fruits like peaches, plums and prunes is expected to be lower than usual.
FOX40 (Sacramento, Calif.), June 7, 2021

Title: Livestock sales underway in Marin County, California
Description:
Marin County ranchers were selling their cattle, having little grass or water for the livestock.  The animals were about 100 pounds lighter each, so no money was made on the sale to a Colorado buyer.
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), June 7, 2021

A North Bay farmer was selling his calves on June 7 and planned to cull 20% to 30% of his 120 cattle because he didn’t have enough water for them.
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), June 4, 2021

Title: Juvenile steelhead moved from Nimbus hatchery to Mokelumne River hatchery in California
Description:
Half a million juvenile steelhead were moved from the Nimbus hatchery to the Mokelumne River hatchery as drought conditions made Folsom Lake too low and warm for the wee fish to keep them there over the summer.  The water at the Nimbus hatchery is expected to be warm this summer, too.  The plan is to return the fish to Nimbus in the fall.
KCRA-TV NBC 3 Sacramento (Calif.), June 9, 2021

Title: Houseboats removed from Lake Oroville in Butte County, California
Description:
Dozens of houseboats needed to be removed from Lake Oroville as water levels fell.  One hundred thirty houseboats were flagged for removal because they were moored in shallow water and could be damaged as water levels continue to fall, per the public safety chief for the Lake Oroville State Recreation Area.  Eighty houseboats were removed from the Bidwell Canyon Marina, while another 50 houseboats were pulled out of the Lime Saddle Marina.  
Lake Oroville was at 718 feet above sea level on May 21 and was forecast to drop below the record low of 645 feet set in September 1977.
KRCR-TV ABC 7 & KCVU-TV Fox 20 (Redding, Calif.), May 21, 2021

Title: Releases from Millerton Lake for salmon on hold through summer
Description:
Water flows from Millerton Lake into the San Joaquin River for the benefit of native salmon will be stopped through early September in an effort to save the water to protect spring-run salmon.  The water will instead be released in early fall.  
GV Wire (Fresno, Calif.), June 3, 2021

Title: Releases from Millerton Lake for salmon on hold through summer
Description:
Water flows from Millerton Lake into the San Joaquin River for the benefit of native salmon will be stopped through early September in an effort to save the water to protect spring-run salmon.  The water will instead be released in early fall.  
GV Wire (Fresno, Calif.), June 3, 2021

Title: Dozens of dry wells near Orland, California
Description:
Dozens of wells in the Orland area went dry, forcing some to haul water.  Many people were reluctant to turn on their pumps for fear of them burning out.
KHSL CBS 12 (Chico, Calif.), May 31, 2021

Title: Boat docks pushed out 75 feet at Big Bear Lake in San Bernardino County, California
Description:
Big Bear Lake was 13.5 feet below full capacity amid the drought.  All marinas have had to push their boat docks about 75 feet to reach the water.  The lake could dip to historically low levels by autumn.
KNBC-TV NBC 4 Los Angeles (Calif.), May 29, 2021

Title: Most boat ramps closed, 5 mph speed limit at Folsom Lake in California
Description:
The low level of Folsom Lake closed all boat ramps except Brown’s Ravine Boat Launch—Folsom Point and Granite Bay were closed.  The Granite Bay Boat Launch now serves at a parking lot and a beach.  The seasonal 5 mph speed limit has been in place since late October 2020, meaning no jet skis, and most boating is off-limits.
FOX 40 (Sacramento, Calif.), May 29, 2021

Title: Most boat ramps closed, 5 mph speed limit at Folsom Lake in California
Description:
The low level of Folsom Lake closed all boat ramps except Brown’s Ravine Boat Launch—Folsom Point and Granite Bay were closed.  The Granite Bay Boat Launch now serves at a parking lot and a beach.  The seasonal 5 mph speed limit has been in place since late October 2020, meaning no jet skis, and most boating is off-limits.
FOX 40 (Sacramento, Calif.), May 29, 2021

The seasonal 5 mph speed limit has been in place since late October 2020, meaning no jet skis, and most boating is off-limits.
FOX 40 (Sacramento, Calif.), May 29, 2021

Title: Lower speed limit, boat ramps closed at Lake Sonoma in California
Description:
The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers extended the “No Wake Zones” for all of Lake Sonoma, except for the widest, deepest part of the lake behind Warm Springs Dam.  Boat speeds were limited to 5 mph or less everywhere else.  Some boat launches were closed.
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), June 1, 2021

Title: Poor grass growth, water hauling, supplemental feeding underway in Sonoma County, California
Description:
Dairy ranchers have been trucking water to their herds since early spring.  Dryland pastures produced less grass.  One dairyman sold about 10% of his herd in February and March, due to the lack of grass.  Organic dairies were particularly challenged because cattle must spend at least 120 days on pasture.
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), June 3, 2021

The warm, dry February has significantly reduced forage production in Sonoma County.  Livestock producers were considering buying feed for their herds, if they weren’t already.  Water supplies were low for dairy cattle. 
Bud break occurred earlier than usual for grape and fruit crops, meaning irrigation will be needed very soon.
Petaluma360 & Petaluma Argus Courier (Calif.), March 12, 2020

Title: Less water, fewer planted acres in Sonoma County, California
Description:
A Sonoma County fruit and vegetable farmer was utilizing just 17 acres, less than 10% of his farmland, to grow crops as they have no seasonal workers and a smaller than normal amount of reclaimed water from the city of Santa Rosa.  Many ranchers and growers throughout the county were having to make tough decisions and cutback also, due to lack of water. 
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), June 3, 2021

Title: Drastic losses to forage, feed and grain crops for livestock in Sonoma County, California
Description:
The Sonoma County Agricultural Commissioner’s office documented significant losses in forage, feed and grain crops grown to feed livestock.  An ongoing county survey indicated that field, forage and silage crop losses have reached the 70% to 85% range, impacting the number of livestock able to be kept locally.  
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), June 3, 2021

Title: Undeveloped grapes, increased disease pressure in Sonoma County, California
Description:
Drought effects were seen on the grapevines through undeveloped grapes and increased disease pressure.  Growers expected a lighter crop, according to the president of Sonoma County Winegrowers.
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), June 3, 2021

Title: Livestock feed purchases, livestock sales in Sonoma County, California
Description:
Livestock producers were looking further away for livestock feed.  Whereas they normally buy hay from the Central Valley, the Klamath Basin and Nevada, some were looking to Utah and Idaho for hay.
Shortages of pasture and water meant more livestock sales because the cost of keeping cattle during drought is too high.  A producer of Hereford seed stock anticipated selling up to 25% of his 600 animals.  
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), June 3, 2021

Title: Older almond trees left unwatered in Solano, Yuba counties in California
Description:
Some older almond trees in the Solano-Yolo county area were left unwatered as farmers opted to irrigate younger trees, trying to make the wisest use of the little water they had.
KCRA-TV NBC 3 Sacramento (Calif.), June 1, 2021

Title: Older almond trees left unwatered in Solano, Yuba counties in California
Description:
Some older almond trees in the Solano-Yolo county area were left unwatered as farmers opted to irrigate younger trees, trying to make the wisest use of the little water they had.
KCRA-TV NBC 3 Sacramento (Calif.), June 1, 2021

Title: State of emergency declaration for Karuk Tribe in northern California
Description:
The Karuk Tribe declared a state of emergency on June 1, due to the historic drought conditions in the Klamath Basin.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation will not release water into the Klamath River for salmon health due to drought conditions.  Consequently, the Karuk and Yurok tribes were finding monitoring traps contained dead juvenile Chinook salmon.  More than 95% of the sampled fish were infected.
KRCR-TV ABC 7 & KCVU-TV Fox 20 (Redding, Calif.), June 2, 2021

Title: State of emergency declaration for Karuk Tribe in northern California
Description:
The Karuk Tribe declared a state of emergency on June 1, due to the historic drought conditions in the Klamath Basin.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation will not release water into the Klamath River for salmon health due to drought conditions.  Consequently, the Karuk and Yurok tribes were finding monitoring traps contained dead juvenile Chinook salmon.  More than 95% of the sampled fish were infected.
KRCR-TV ABC 7 & KCVU-TV Fox 20 (Redding, Calif.), June 2, 2021

Title: Increased voluntary water conservation requested in Santa Clara County, California
Description:
The federal government announced water cuts to urban areas of more than half, which will lead the Santa Clara Valley Water District to rely more on recycled water, groundwater and water purchased from other agencies and farm districts in the state.
The San Jose Mercury News (Calif.), May 27, 2021

The Santa Clara Valley Water District’s Board of Directors met on April 27 and opted to call for conservation of 25% rather than 20%.  The board also voted unanimously to double the price it pays homeowners to use drought-tolerant landscaping from $1 per square foot to $2.  The district serves nearly two million people in Santa Clara County.
KGO-TV ABC 7 San Francisco (Calif.), April 28, 2021

Title: Some salmon deaths occurred in California's Sacramento River
Description:
Twenty-five adult salmon were found dead in the Sacramento River as the water temperature rose above 61 degrees, according to the California Department of Fish and Wildlife.  Observations included "live fish that are exhibiting unusual swimming behavior, fish covered with fungus patches and unspawned fish drifting downstream while still alive but moribund and presumed to die shortly after observation.”  River water temperatures have since fallen.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), May 27, 2021

Title: Some salmon deaths occurred in California's Sacramento River
Description:
Twenty-five adult salmon were found dead in the Sacramento River as the water temperature rose above 61 degrees, according to the California Department of Fish and Wildlife.  Observations included "live fish that are exhibiting unusual swimming behavior, fish covered with fungus patches and unspawned fish drifting downstream while still alive but moribund and presumed to die shortly after observation.”  River water temperatures have since fallen.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), May 27, 2021

Title: Outdoor landscape watering forbidden in California's Westlands Water District
Description:
The Westlands Water District forbade all outdoor landscape watering as the district received less water than anticipated from the Central Valley Project.  
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 26, 2021

Title: Outdoor landscape watering forbidden in California's Westlands Water District
Description:
The Westlands Water District forbade all outdoor landscape watering as the district received less water than anticipated from the Central Valley Project.  
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 26, 2021

Title: Many dead trees in East Bay regional parks in California
Description:
Lack of rain was thought to be responsible for the many dead or dying trees in East Bay Regional Parks.  Fire officials feared that the dead trees could easily fuel fires which could destroy homes.  The affected trees were acacia, eucalyptus, Monterey pines, manzanitas and others.
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), May 25, 2021

Title: Allocations updated for California's Central Valley Project
Description:
The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced on May 26 that municipal water agencies that get water from the Central Valley Project would receive just 25% of their allocation, down from the previous estimate of 55%, to a low not seen since drought in 2015.  
Reclamation also announced that most farm-irrigation districts belonging to the Central Valley Project would get no water in 2021, despite the previous estimate of 5%.
San Luis Obispo Tribune (Calif.), May 26, 2021

Farmers north of the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta learned that they will not receive even 5% of contracted water from the Central Valley Project.  Water deliveries were suspended, due to limited supply, according to the Bureau of Reclamation. 
The San Joaquin Valley Sun (Fresno, Calif.), May 5, 2021

Water deliveries will be delayed for most customers of the Central Valley Project, and no date was given for when the water would be released.  Many of the project's customers are agricultural.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), March 23, 2021

The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced its initial allocation of 5% for the Central Valley Project.  The figure will be updated if more rain and snow fall to improve the allocation.  The CVP serves farm irrigation districts in the Sacramento and San Joaquin valleys.
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 23, 2021

Farmers north of the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta learned that they will not receive even 5% of contracted water from the Central Valley Project.  Water deliveries were suspended, due to limited supply, according to the Bureau of Reclamation. 
The San Joaquin Valley Sun (Fresno, Calif.), May 5, 2021

Water deliveries will be delayed for most customers of the Central Valley Project, and no date was given for when the water would be released.  Many of the project's customers are agricultural.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), March 23, 2021

The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced its initial allocation of 5% for the Central Valley Project.  The figure will be updated if more rain and snow fall to improve the allocation.  The CVP serves farm irrigation districts in the Sacramento and San Joaquin valleys.
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), Feb. 23, 2021

Title: Allocations updated for California's Central Valley Project
Description:
The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation announced on May 26 that municipal water agencies that get water from the Central Valley Project would receive just 25% of their allocation, down from the previous estimate of 55%, to a low not seen since drought in 2015.  
Reclamation also announced that most farm-irrigation districts belonging to the Central Valley Project would get no water in 2021, despite the previous estimate of 5%.
San Luis Obispo Tribune (Calif.), May 26, 2021

Title: No water through Klamath Project's main canal in southern Oregon, northern California
Description:
The Bureau of Reclamation announced that Klamath Project’s A Canal will remain closed for the 2021 irrigation season, meaning that irrigators’ already low allocation of 33,000 acre-feet of water has been canceled.  Concrete bulkheads were lowered into the canal’s headworks, preventing any water from flowing into the canal, making 2021 the first year since the A Canal began operating in 1907 that it will not deliver water.  
Reclamation also announced that a Klamath River surface flushing flow, which would have mitigated salmon disease outbreaks below Iron Gate Dam, will not be performed this year.
Leaving the canals dry allows them to crumble and crack, causing significant damage to the infrastructure that must be repaired.
Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), May 12, 2021

The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation will not release water for dying salmon or for the six wildlife refuges that host millions of migrating birds annually.  Initially irrigators were told they would receive a small amount of water, but instead the water has been shut off.  
KMPH Fox 26 News (Fresno, Calif.), May 24, 2021

The Klamath Project will receive 33,000 acre-feet in 2021, about one-tenth the average amount, for the lowest amount in the project’s history.  Due to drought and low inflows into Upper Klamath Lake, water deliveries will begin on June 1, about two months later than usual.
The bureau also announced $15 million in immediate aid to the Klamath Project through the Klamath Project Drought Relief Agency, an additional $3 million in technical assistance to tribes for ecosystem activities in the basin, and also funding for groundwater monitoring in the basin.
Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), April 14, 2021

Title: Young salmon dying in the Klamath River in northern California
Description:
Young salmon have been dying in the Klamath River since May 4, according to the Yurok Tribal Fisheries Department, which noted that 97% of the juvenile salmon were infected with C. shasta, a disease that kills the fish within days. 
High Country News (Paonia, Colo.), May 27, 2021

Title: Klamath Project irrigators seeking more financial help
Description:
Klamath area farm groups were asking for additional funding to help farmers endure extreme drought and avoid economic devastation.  Reclamation has offered to provide $15 million for agricultural producers through the Klamath Project Drought Response Agency, and $3 million in technical assistance for local tribes to benefit endangered fish, but irrigators were in such dire straits that more assistance was needed.
Klamath Falls Herald and News (Oregon), May 27, 2021

Title: Klamath Project irrigators seeking more financial help
Description:

Klamath Falls Herald and News (Oregon), May 27, 2021

Title: Rice production slashed in Butte County, California as water supply is halved
Description:
Butte County rice growers have less water available and will grow less rice.  One rice farmer who usually grows 1,400 acres of rice will plant just 800 acres this year because that is all they will have water to irrigate.  He estimated that county rice growers will plant 10% to 50% less rice after their water allocation was cut by 50%.
KRCR-TV ABC 7 & KCVU-TV Fox 20 (Redding, Calif.), May 24, 2021

Title: Grass, pasture were concerns for cattle producers in Marin County,
Description:
Cattle producers in western Marin County were concerned about feeding their livestock as pastures that ought to be waist-high were inch high stubble instead.  Water was an even bigger problem than grass as natural springs dried up or barely trickled, leading some to truck in water for animals.  Ranchers were planning to sell some of their herds for slaughter.
CBS SF Bay Area (San Francisco, Calif.), May 25, 2021

Title: Mandatory restrictions for California's Upper Russian River
Description:
The California Water Resources Control Board on May 26 issued new restrictions on water diversions in the Upper Russian River basin to protect fish habitat and drinking water supplies.  The restrictions affect 930 junior water right holders with rights dating back to 1914.  
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), May 26, 2021

Title: Mandatory restrictions for California's Upper Russian River
Description:
The California Water Resources Control Board on May 26 issued new restrictions on water diversions in the Upper Russian River basin to protect fish habitat and drinking water supplies.  The restrictions affect 930 junior water right holders with rights dating back to 1914.  
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), May 26, 2021

Title: Low water level of Lake Tahoe closed boat ramps
Description:
The low level of Lake Tahoe meant that the Tahoe Vista Recreation Area boat launch will not be open for motorized boat launches during the 2021 boating season, but non-motorized crafts can launch there.  Boat launches on the south shore’s El Dorado Beach were also closed to motorized craft.
Boat ramps at Lake Forest Beach along the north shore, Obexer’s on the west shore, and Cave Rock on the east shore will be open.  
Lake Tahoe reached its lowest level on May 19 at 6,225 feet, not far above the natural rim of 6,223 feet.
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), May 21, 2021

The Sierra Nevada snowpack has nearly completely melted, but did not refill Lake Tahoe, which was 2.5 feet lower than this time in 2020 and at its lowest point in five years.  Without additional precipitation, Lake Tahoe could reach a critical low point this summer with lake levels reaching the rim by late summer, meaning outflows would slow.
The boat ramp at El Dorado Beach will not be open to motorized boats this year, due to low water levels.  The water was also shallow at the Tahoe Vista boat ramp.
SFGate (San Francisco, Calif.), May 12, 2021

Description:
Blue oak trees in the San Francisco Bay Area were dying from lack of moisture.  
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), May 24, 2021

Title: Cal Fire suspended burn permits in several California counties
Description:
Cal Fire suspended burn permits in Santa Clara, Alameda, Contra Costa counties, as well as the western portions of Stanislaus and San Joaquin counties, effective May 17.  The action came in response to hot, dry weather that heightened the fire danger.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), May 13, 2021

Title: Sonoma County, California farmers unable to grow crops for lack of water
Description:
Farmers north of San Francisco were withdrawing from local farmers markets and produce-box programs for lack of water to grow crops.  One Petaluma farm operator posted to their Instagram page that they do not have enough water to grow their usual crops for the first time in 21 years.  Other farms in the area were facing the same challenge.
Bloomberg (New York, N.Y.), May 18, 2021

Title: Burn permits suspended in San Mateo, Santa Cruz counties in California
Description:
The California Department of Forestry and Fire Prevention suspended burn permits in San Mateo and Santa Cruz counties, effective May 20.  Dead grass and hot, dry conditions led to the suspension, which prohibits all outdoor burning, except campfires within organized campgrounds or on private property.
Since the start of 2021, Cal Fire and firefighters statewide have already responded to more than 2,060 wildfires.
Menlo Park Almanac (Calif.), May 20, 2021

Title: Burn permits suspended in San Mateo, Santa Cruz counties in California

Title: Drought emergency declaration for Marin County, California
Description:
The Marin County Board of Supervisors unanimously declared a drought emergency on May 18, due to historic dry conditions.  Rainfall was a record low during the past winter, leading Marin water suppliers to impose mandatory water restrictions.  The county intends to request to be added to the list of 41 California counties already in an emergency drought declaration.
Water sources have gone dry months earlier than normal for many dairy and beef cattle ranchers, particularly in the West Marin area.  Supplemental hay and feed was needed months earlier, also as pasture quality was poor.  The McClure Dairy, the oldest one on the Point Reyes National Seashore, closed and more may follow.  Roughly 50% of the county’s 300 acres of crop production may be fallowed, due to drought.
The North Marin Water District enacted a temporary ban on new water connections. The Marin Municipal Water District board intends to also consider a temporary ban on new water meter connections.
Marin Independent Journal (San Rafael, Calif.), May 18, 2021

Title: Water districts near Sacramento, California urged to rely on groundwater more
Description:
As the level of Folsom Lake fell to one of its lowest points ever, the Sacramento Regional Water Authority was urging its 20 water districts in the Sacramento area to rely more on groundwater than surface water to reduce reliance on Folsom Lake and the Lower American River.
CBS Sacramento (Calif.), May 14, 2021

Title: Phase II water emergency in St. Helena, California
Description:
St. Helena remained in a Phase II water emergency, and water rationing was in effect. 
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), May 11, 2021

St. Helena officials adopted a sliding scale of fines, effective June 1 for water customers who exceed their allowed consumption during the emergency.  
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), May 5, 2021

New penalties will be imposed on St. Helena water customers who exceed their rations beginning May 1 as the Phase II water emergency continued.  The penalties must be approved at an upcoming April 13 council meeting. The city allocates 65 gallons per person daily, plus 2,500 gallons per month for outdoor use.  
St. Helena’s Bell Canyon Reservoir is at 42% of capacity.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), March 24, 2021

The Phase II water emergency remained in effect for St. Helena.  Bell Canyon Reservoir had an elevation of 400.11 feet, or about 40% of capacity.  
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), March 10, 2021

Drought and increased water demand for firefighting led St. Helena authorities to declare a Phase II water emergency and order mandatory rationing.  Bell Canyon Reservoir was at 38.8 percent of capacity after a year of meager rainfall yielding just 20 inches.  An unknown amount of water was also used to fight the LNU Lightning Complex and Glass fires.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Oct 28, 2020

Title: Burn permits suspended in six northern California counties
Description:
Cal Fire suspended burn permits in the six northern California counties of Napa, Solano, Sonoma, Colusa, Lake and Yolo, due to ongoing drought and a fire season that has begun early.  The suspension begins May 10 and prohibits all residential outdoor burning of landscape debris in areas of state responsibility within the six counties. 
NBC Bay Area (San Jose, Calif.), May 6, 2021

Title: Rice farmers in California's Sacramento Valley fallowing rice fields
Description:
About 100,000 acres less rice will be grown in California, due to low water supplies, according to the CEO of the California Rice Commission.  One rice grower was pumping more groundwater than usual and was forced to fallow half of his rice fields.  The reduction in rice grown is expected to hurt small communities north of Sacramento that depend on rice for jobs in milling, processing and shipping.
CBS Sacramento (Calif.), May 6, 2021

CBS Sacramento (Calif.), May 6, 2021

Title: Santa Clara County, California ranchers purchasing feed, hay as grasses were short
Description:
Pastures in Santa Clara County offered short, stubby grasses for grazing as little rain fell to stimulate growth, forcing ranchers to purchase feed and hay, sometimes from three states away, according to a local rancher.
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), May 6, 2021

Title: Water rate increase for Santa Clara Valley Water District in California
Description:
The Santa Clara Valley Water District board of directors approved a 9.1 percent rate increase for the 2022 fiscal year.  The rate increase was needed to help pay for additional emergency water, conservation programs, expanded use of recycled water, an environmental impact report for the proposed Pacheco Reservoir Expansion Project, and start the work on the dam seismic retrofit project.  County residents can expect to pay an additional $4.30 to $4.82 monthly from July 1, 2021 through June 30, 2022.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), May 12, 2021

Title: Field of asparagus destroyed in Fresno County, California
Description:
Some Central Valley farmers were destroying their crops, knowing that they will not have enough water to bring them to harvest.  Lost crops equals lost jobs for farmworkers and likely smaller quantities of more expensive produce in the grocery store.
A field of asparagus in Fresno County was destroyed to leave water for other crops and will put 50 to 60 farmworkers out of a job next year.
KGPE-TV CBS 47 Fresno (Calif.), May 12, 2021

Title: Almond trees removed, citrus picked early in California's Central Valley
Description:
Limited water supplies led California farmers to take drastic steps to efficiently use the water they have.  A Fresno County farmer removed nearly 400 acres of 15-year old, prime-production almond trees because there was not enough water to irrigate them this year since his 5% allocation from the Central Valley Project was suspended.  The only water available for purchase was astronomically priced at $1,500 to $2,000 per acre-foot.
A citrus grower with farmland in Fresno, Tulare and Kern counties, said he harvested about 80 acres of citrus a month and a half early, "to save water for other ranches."
Ag Alert (Sacramento, Calif.), May 12, 2021

Title: Drought, water supply main factor in dairy closing in Marin County, California
Description:
The largest and oldest dairy in the Point Reyes National Seashore is closing, leaving eight families without housing or work.  The dairy owner listed a number of reasons for closing, but drought and the fear of running out of water topped the list.  Six hundred fifty cows were sold, and the staff was laid off. The ranch’s single spring was historically abundant, but was no longer recharging.  Grass was growing more slowly, forcing the purchase of feed.  A glut of organic milk meant prices were down.
Point Reyes Light (Point Reyes Station, Calif.), May 12, 2021

Title: California officials warned to prepare for dry wells in Central Valley
Description:
California’s last drought affected rural, low-income Latino communities most in terms of drinking water shortages as Central Valley wells went dry.  A report from the Legislative Analyst’s Office warned state officials to prepare by increasing the monitoring of wells in at risk communities and having water ready to deliver.
A report from the California Natural Resources Agency listed 2,600 reports of dry wells received through January 2019, mostly in 2014 and 2015.  The figure was recognized as an undercount.
Cal Matters (Sacramento, Calif.), May 13, 2021

Title: Giant sequoia smoldering in California's Sequoia National Park
Description:
A giant sequoia in the Sequoia National Park was discovered on May 5 to be still smoldering after a lightning-sparked wildfire in August 2020, according to the National Park Service.  After a winter of low snowfall and rain, there could be additional smoldering fires discovered as summer nears.
Associated Press, May 5, 2021

Title: Smoldering trees reignite in Santa Cruz mountains of California
Description:
Redwood trees within the CZU Lightning Complex fire burn scar in the Santa Cruz mountains were still smoldering after the blaze was declared 100% contained by Cal Fire eight months ago.  The fires could reignite after a dry winter as precipitation was not sufficient to snuff the smoldering tree roots.  Such reignition fires in Big Basin were documented in the early 1900s.
Cal Fire plans to fly a plane with heat-detecting infrared technology to find embers in the CZU burn scar.
KRON4 (San Francisco, Calif.), May 6, 2021

Title: Water shortage emergency, more stringent water restrictions in Marin County, California
Description:
Marin Municipal Water District approved more stringent water restrictions on May 4 as reservoirs were historically low at about 50% of capacity amid drought, compared to an average of more than 90% capacity for this time of year.  Spray irrigation was limited to twice weekly, and drip irrigation may only be done three times per week.  Covers for pools and spas were mandated.
The board declared a water shortage emergency on April 20.
NBC Bay Area (San Jose, Calif.), May 5, 2021

Title: Drought forcing vineyards, dairies, farmers to conserve in Sonoma County, California
Description:
Sonoma County vineyards have pruned grape vines so they will produce less fruit and need less water.  Having water for frost protection is also a big concern for vineyards as frost can be a threat through the latter part of May.  Farm reservoirs were low, offering little for irrigation or frost protection.  Another water-conserving measure one vineyard took was to mow off the cover crops between the vines so there was less competition for rain that might fall. 
Dairy ranchers fear grasslands will turn brown earlier than usual, have sold cattle and were already trucking water for livestock.  Vegetable farmers have adjusted cropping plans to grow vegetables that will offer the largest yield while using less water.  Cannabis growers’ well water use is metered under a specific cap, barely allowing them enough water to get a crop.
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), April 30, 2021

Title: California snow survey canceled
Description:
California’s Department of Water Resources canceled the April 29 snow survey at Phillips Station for lack of snow.  Much of the low elevation snow had melted, while snow at higher elevations was starting to melt.
KCRA-TV NBC 3 Sacramento (Calif.), April 29, 2021

Title: Drought state of emergency declaration for Mendocino County, California
Description:
A drought state of emergency was declared for Mendocino County by the board of supervisors.  An ad hoc drought committee was also created.  
The Mendocino Voice (Calif.), April 22, 2021

Title: Less water being released for minimum protection of imperiled fish in upper Russian River in California
Description:
Sonoma Water received permission from state regulators to release less water than normally required for minimum protection of imperiled salmon and steelhead trout in the upper Russian River.  The water district was also petitioning for lowered in-stream flows for the full length of the river. 
Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), April 26, 2021

Title: Less water being released for minimum protection of imperiled fish in upper Russian River in California
Description:
Sonoma Water received permission from state regulators to release less water than normally required for minimum protection of imperiled salmon and steelhead trout in the upper Russian River.  The water district was also petitioning for lowered in-stream flows for the full length of the river. 
Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), April 26, 2021

Title: Drought, other factors led to closing of winery in Marin County, California
Description:
Grape yields at Pey-Marin Vineyards were very low in drought years.  Climate change and weather extremes made grape growing in west Marin County not worth the effort, leading the owner to close the winery.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), April 27, 2021

Title: Young salmon in California being trucked to sea
Description:
Tanker trucks were being used to transport about 16.8 million young salmon from four Central Valley hatcheries to the San Francisco Bay and other coastal sites  as drought left rivers too low, too warm or both for the smolts’ survival.  About 20% more fish than normal were being trucked to the Pacific Ocean.  The aim is to maximize survival of California’s fall-run chinook, central to the state’s commercial and recreational salmon industries.  
The chinook typically start their lives upriver and swim to the Pacific Ocean, where they stay for three years until they return to where they were born to spawn.  
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), April 29, 2021

Young 3.5-inch long salmon were being trucked from the Nimbus Fish Hatchery east of Sacramento to the San Francisco Bay, rather than being released into the American River as usual because drought left the river too warm for the wee fish.  Seventeen million salmon smolts will be transported to the San Francisco Bay from hatcheries, a measure last taken during the 2014 drought.
The American River was flowing at 31% of its usual rate on May 11 and was warm enough to threaten the hundreds of thousands of fry and eggs laid naturally in the river.
Reuters (New York, N.Y.), May 13, 2021

Young 3.5-inch long salmon were being trucked from the Nimbus Fish Hatchery east of Sacramento to the San Francisco Bay, rather than being released into the American River as usual because drought left the river too warm for the wee fish.  Seventeen million salmon smolts will be transported to the San Francisco Bay from hatcheries, a measure last taken during the 2014 drought.
The American River was flowing at 31% of its usual rate on May 11 and was warm enough to threaten the hundreds of thousands of fry and eggs laid naturally in the river.
Reuters (New York, N.Y.), May 13, 2021

Title: Young salmon in California being trucked to sea
Description:
Tanker trucks were being used to transport about 16.8 million young salmon from four Central Valley hatcheries to the San Francisco Bay and other coastal sites  as drought left rivers too low, too warm or both for the smolts’ survival.  About 20% more fish than normal were being trucked to the Pacific Ocean.  The aim is to maximize survival of California’s fall-run chinook, central to the state’s commercial and recreational salmon industries.  
The chinook typically start their lives upriver and swim to the Pacific Ocean, where they stay for three years until they return to where they were born to spawn.  
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), April 29, 2021

Young 3.5-inch long salmon were being trucked from the Nimbus Fish Hatchery east of Sacramento to the San Francisco Bay, rather than being released into the American River as usual because drought left the river too warm for the wee fish.  Seventeen million salmon smolts will be transported to the San Francisco Bay from hatcheries, a measure last taken during the 2014 drought.
The American River was flowing at 31% of its usual rate on May 11 and was warm enough to threaten the hundreds of thousands of fry and eggs laid naturally in the river.
Reuters (New York, N.Y.), May 13, 2021

Title: Drought emergency for Nevada Irrigation District in California
Description:
A drought emergency was proclaimed on April 28 for the Nevada Irrigation District in preparation for expanding drought and reduced water supplies.  As part of the drought emergency, the district also entered its Stage 1 Drought Contingency Plan and requested the customers curb their water use by 10%.  
Drought conditions in the district stem from below normal precipitation in March and April; high winds and above-average temperature that dried the watershed; and irrigation season startup demands are at mid-summer levels.  Conservation was needed to ensure that the district has adequate supplies to continue delivering water next year should the drought continue.  
The district’s service area included parts of Nevada, Placer and Yuba counties. 
YubaNet (Nevada City, Calif.), April 29, 2021

Title: Super bloom in lakebed of Folsom Lake in California
Description:
A super bloom of lupine covered parts of the Folsom Lake lakebed in the Beeks Bight nature area in Granite Bay as historically low rainfall left the lake unusually low.  Folsom Lake is at 37% of capacity and 50% of the historical average for April 27, according to the California Department of Water Resources Data Exchange Center.
KGO-TV ABC 7 San Francisco (Calif.), April 27, 2021

Title: California's San Diego County Water Authority selling water to help drier parts of state
Description:
The San Diego County Water Authority was looking to help other water districts by sharing its water supplies.  Decades of investment in supply reliability, combined with water-use efficiency, leave the San Diego County district with adequate supplies to weather multiple dry years. 
Times of San Diego (Calif.), April 24, 2021

Title: Shallow wells in California's San Joaquin Valley at risk of running dry
Description:
Shallow wells in the San Joaquin Valley may be at risk of running dry this summer as California endures a second dry year, leading farmers to rely more heavily on pumping groundwater.  A Riverdale well driller in Fresno County reported that he received 15 to 20 calls before noon on April 16 from residents in Fresno and Kings counties who needed pumps lowered or a new well drilled.  The well driller and others anticipate that this second consecutive dry year will cause many dry shallow wells in the valley and crisis for homeowners who cannot afford the cost of a new well.  
During the 2012-2016 drought, more than 2,000 residential wells in the Valley went dry.
The Fresno Bee (Calif.), April 22, 2021

Title: Drought economic disaster relief sought for Klamath Basin parties in Oregon, California
Description:
Klamath Basin Tribes, conservationists and commercial fishermen sent a letter to President Biden for extreme Drought Economic Disaster Relief.  The groups requested more than $250 million in funding to address immediate economic losses and for help in restoring water balance to, and improve ecological conditions in, the Klamath Basin.   
KRCR-TV ABC 7 & KCVU-TV Fox 20 (Redding, Calif.), April 22, 2021

The groups requested more than $250 million in funding to address immediate economic losses and for help in restoring water balance to, and improve ecological conditions in, the Klamath Basin.

Title: Less water for the South San Joaquin Irrigation District in California
Description:
The South San Joaquin Irrigation District learned that runoff from the Stanislaus River watershed would be 20,000 to 40,000 acre-feet of water less than the previous estimate.  The SSJID might not receive more than 225,000 acre-feet, compared to 2020 when the district received 249,000 acre-feet, as inflow to the Melones Dam was expected to be far below normal.  Plans were scrapped to release up to 100,000 acre feet to boost the spring pulse flow for threatened fish in the Stanislaus River and then sell that water to west side farmers that are without state water this year for lack of water.
Escalon Times (Oakdale, Calif.), April 13, 2021

Title: Limited recycled water available for farmers in Sonoma County, California
Description:
Santa Rosa will deliver just a third of the recycled water that farmers normally get.  The city typically provides 1.7 billion gallons for 60 users, but this year only has 600 million gallons. 
North Bay Business Journal (Santa Rosa, Calif.), April 14, 2021

Title: Thinned herds, variances sought in Sonoma County, California
Description:
The executive director of the Sonoma County Farm Bureau stated, “Some farmers have thinned out their herds, and some dairyman are asking for a variance, and others are planting less,” amid drought and limited water supplies.
North Bay Business Journal (Santa Rosa, Calif.), April 14, 2021

Title: Disruption in agricultural water supply to Santa Rosa Junior College in Sonoma County, California
Description:
The Sonoma County Water Agency cutting off Santa Rosa Junior College’s secondary agricultural water supply to its farm from April to October, due to the drought, according to the Dean of Agriculture. Its primary supply comes from the city of Windsor.
North Bay Business Journal (Santa Rosa, Calif.), April 14, 2021

Title: California's Metropolitan Water District seeking to bolster supplies
Description:
The Metropolitan Water District intends to spend up to $44 million to purchase up to 65,000 acre-feet of water from water agencies north of the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta to provide adequate water supplies for Southern California amid a second consecutive dry year.  Metropolitan expects to get just 5% of its contracted allocation from the State Water Project, would like to bolster supplies in case drought continues and is offering up to $675 per acre-foot of water, which is two to three times normal water prices.  Although during the last drought, prices on the open market exceeded $1,000.
MWD provides water for 19 million people in six counties in Southern California.
The Sacramento Bee (Calif.), April 13, 2021

Title: Rubber dam inflated one month early on the Russian River in California
Description:
Sonoma County water managers inflated a seasonal rubber dam on the Russian River a month early in an effort to retain as much water as possible in the reservoirs after an unusually dry winter.
The public is also encouraged to conserve water.  
The Santa Rosa Press Democrat (Calif.), April 15, 2021

Title: Hay farmer irrigating early, stressed about meager water supplies in Tulelake, California
Description:
A hay farmer in Tulelake, California began watering his fields earlier than ever this year, but runoff in Klamath Lake was late.  Upper Klamath Lake levels were about a foot lower than normal for this time of year, and inflows to Upper Klamath Lake were the lowest on record.
The hay farmer stated, "I'm frightened, scared to death actually. You know, I'm a younger guy starting out farming and I've got mortgages to pay, pay the landowners and without being able to produce a crop, and this year is looking to be devastating.  I mean we're looking at zeroing fields out."
Klamath County received a drought declaration from Gov. Brown last week as water supplies were unusually low.
KTVL - Channel 10 News (Medford, Ore.), April 8, 2021

Title: Hay farmer irrigating early, stressed about meager water supplies in Tulelake, California
Description:
A hay farmer in Tulelake, California began watering his fields earlier than ever this year, but runoff in Klamath Lake was late.  Upper Klamath Lake levels were about a foot lower than normal for this time of year, and inflows to Upper Klamath Lake were the lowest on record.

Title: California's Marin Municipal Water District urging voluntary conservation
Description:
For the first time since 2013, the Marin Municipal Water District urged customers to voluntarily curb their water use as rainfall was low like during the 1976-77 drought.  No specific conservation target was set forth, but a 22 percent voluntary reduction would significantly help MMWD’s water storage outlook.  As of Feb. 15, reservoirs held 66 percent of average capacity.
A 20 percent drop in water use would mean an estimated loss of $8 million in revenue for MMWD.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), Feb. 18, 2021

Title: Fallowed land, alternate feed plans in Tulare County, California
Description:
The expectation of little irrigation water has a Tulare County farmer and dairy operator fallowing some land and purchasing baled mixes of hay rather than growing his own.
Farmers who rely on Central Valley Project water were unsure how to plan since the announcement that the 5% allocation would be delayed.  Growers have tried to buy water on the market, but there was little available.
Ag Alert (Sacramento, Calif.), April 7, 2021

Title: Dry pond, stockpiled hay in Sonoma County, California
Description:
Rainfall in Sonoma County has been 5 inches of rain, rather than the 18 to 19 inches typically received.  A pond that should be running over was dry with a cracked bottom, although the land owners since 1976 had never seen it empty before.  They have stockpiled hay and paid tens of thousands of dollars for a water delivery truck.  
KGO-TV ABC7 San Francisco (Calif.), April 6, 2021

Title: San Joaquin Valley legislators pushing California governor to declare drought
Description:
San Joaquin Valley legislators were pushing Gov. Gavin Newsom to declare a state of emergency over California’s continuing water crisis as the state appeared to be entering another drought.  The Senate Agriculture Committee chairman Andreas Borgeas (R–Fresno), Assembly Agriculture Committee chairman Robert Rivas (D–Hollister) and other legislators sent a letter to the governor, requesting that he declare a statewide emergency due to drought.  The declaration would allow state agencies to be able to increase water allocations south of the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta, and give lawmakers direct meetings with officials leading the California Department of Water Resources.
The San Joaquin Valley Sun (Calif.), April 7, 2021
