San Joaquin Valley legislators were pushing Gov. Gavin Newsom to declare a state of emergency over California’s continuing water crisis as the state appeared to be entering another drought. Title: Water supplies nearly depleted, grass short in Sonoma County, California
Description:
Water supplies on a Sonoma County dairy farm were nearly dry, and surrounding dryland pasture growth was stunted.  The farmer was preparing to begin hauling water for his livestock in the coming weeks as he and other area dairies struggled to provide enough water for their animals.  A less fortunate neighbor has been hauling water from the city since 2020 as two consecutive dry years emptied his reservoirs.
Grass was only a few inches tall, whereas it ought to be several feet tall, according to the executive director of Sonoma County Farm Bureau.  Without more rain, the grass will dry up quickly.
The Petaluma Argus-Courier (Calif.), April 1, 2021

Title: Drought cutting into tule elk populations in Point Reyes National Seashore in California
Description:
The population of the largest tule elk herd in the Point Reyes National Seashore fell by about a third, due to overpopulation and malnutrition after two years of below normal rainfall.  
The Tomales Point herd dropped from 445 elk in the winter of 2019-2020 to 293 in the winter that just ended, according to the latest survey.  The decline is the largest in the herd since the 2013-2015 drought, when 250 elk died under similar conditions, park officials said.  Drought reduced the nutritional value of the forage grasses and plants that the elk consume, but drinking water was not lacking.  
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), March 31, 2021

Title: Dry water year for Turlock Irrigation District in California
Description:
The Turlock Irrigation District announced a 34-inch water cap allotment for the district’s irrigation season, which will begin on March 18.    Last year’s water cap was 42 inches, but a second year of below average rainfall and a historically dry year of 54% of average precipitation since the water year began reduced the cap.
Previous drought years of 2014, 2015 and 2016 saw the water cap at 20, 18 and 36 inches, respectively. 
The Turlock Journal (Calif.), March 9, 2021

With the 2020-21 water year being the second consecutive dry year and sixth driest on record to date, the Turlock Irrigation District water allotment may be just 34 inches.  The upcoming March snowpack survey and a planned airborne snow survey will provide more information on the amount of water available for growers.  The Tuolumne snowpack measured just 55.6% of the historical average for the date. 
Turlock Journal (Calif.), Feb. 23, 2021

Title: Poppies scarce in Riverside County, California
Description:
Scarcely any poppies could be found in Walker Canyon in the Lake Elsinore area as the past winter was dry.  Some tourists still arrived, hoping to see a superbloom, like in 2019.  The poppies were scarce in 2020 also.
Riverside Press-Enterprise (Calif.), March 26, 2021

Title: Notices sent to California water users
Description:
The State Water Board sent notices to California’s 40,000 water users, including small farms and big cities, to alert them to prepare for cuts in water deliveries.  This is the first step before ordering an end to water draws.
San Francisco Chronicle (Calif.), March 23, 2021

Title: Notices sent to California water users

Title: Updated water allocation of 5% for California's State Water Project
Description:
The California Department of Water Resources updated its initial water allocation for the 2021 water year to 5% of requested supplies, down from 10% as announced in December 2020.  The allocation will be finalized by May.  The State Water Project serves more than 27 million people and provides irrigation for about 750,000 acres of farmland, mostly in the San Joaquin Valley.
YubaNet (Calif.), March 23, 2021

The California Department of Water Resources announced the initial water allocation of 10 percent for the State Water Project.  While the initial allocation was low, the allocation last year was also 10 percent, but was increased to 20 percent in May 2020. 
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Dec. 1 2020

Title: Temporary Urgency Change Order for Lake Mendocino, California
Description:
Sonoma County Water Agency implemented a Temporary Urgency Change Order stating that it can immediately reduce the amount of water it releases from Lake Mendocino, conserving water in the lake due to low water storage levels caused by dry weather conditions.
Ukiah Daily Journal (Calif.), March 17, 2021

Title: Temporary Urgency Change Order for Lake Mendocino, California
Description:
Sonoma County Water Agency implemented a Temporary Urgency Change Order stating that it can immediately reduce the amount of water it releases from Lake Mendocino, conserving water in the lake due to low water storage levels caused by dry weather conditions.
Ukiah Daily Journal (Calif.), March 17, 2021

Title: Winter wheat, other grain growth slowed in California
Description:
Winter wheat and other grains in California were growing more slowly than usual, due to drought, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  Winter wheat is grown across California with the main production areas located in Fresno, Kern, Kings and Tulare counties in the San Joaquin Valley and Yolo County in the Sacramento Valley. 
Bloomberg (New York), March 20, 2021

Bloomberg (New York), March 20, 2021

Title: Winter wheat, other grain growth slowed in California
Description:
Winter wheat and other grains in California were growing more slowly than usual, due to drought, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.  Winter wheat is grown across California with the main production areas located in Fresno, Kern, Kings and Tulare counties in the San Joaquin Valley and Yolo County in the Sacramento Valley. 
Bloomberg (New York), March 20, 2021

Title: Water conservation urged for customers of the Santa Clara Valley Water District in California
Description:
Customers of the Santa Clara Valley Water District were urged to increase their conservation efforts, but no water restrictions were mandated just yet.  Other large water agencies in the Bay Area were similarly asking customers to conserve, but were not yet taking a tougher approach.  The SCVWD, serving 2 million people in the Silicon Valley, will make the decision on future restrictions by May and will be seeking to purchase water from other parts of the state to bolster its supplies.  
The district’s 10 reservoirs were 16% full on March 16. The Sierra Nevada snowpack was 61% of normal. Most Bay Area cities received only about 40% of the historic average rainfall this winter.
The SCVWD’s largest reservoir, Anderson Reservoir, was drained last year over federal regulators’ concerns that the dam could collapse if a major earthquake occurred. 
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), March 17, 2021

Title: Emergency water conservation rules for customers in Novato, California
Description:
The North Marin Water District approved emergency conservation rules for Novato residents and businesses as rainfall remained scarce.  Just about 8 inches of rain fell at the Stafford Lake reservoir since July, a record low since record-keeping began in 1916.  The ordinance that the board adopted will allow the district the ability to enact stricter measures more quickly if needed in the near future, once updates are received from the Sonoma County Water Agency in about one month.  
In the meantime, water users were urged to continue conserving water.  The district serves about 61,000 residents in the greater Novato area.
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), March 17, 2021

Title: Water shortage emergency a possibility for North Marin Water District in California
Description:
The North Marin Water District was considering a water shortage emergency as Stafford Lake was at 30% of capacity.
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), March 2, 2021

The North Marin Water District is considering whether a voluntary or mandatory water conservation order was needed in Novato, due to historically low rainfall.  The district received just 7 inches, the least amount since record keeping began in 1916.  
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.)
Feb. 27, 2021

Title: Growers in South San Joaquin Irrigation District in California urged to be wise with water use
Description:
The South San Joaquin Irrigation District will begin its irrigation season on March 10. The district board considered starting the season with reduced allocations, but opted to begin with a full allocation and urge growers to be wise with water use.  If inflow to New Melones Reservoir is below 600,000 acre-feet, SSJID will have to draw from their conservation account at New Melones, which is rarely needed and could trigger water allocations.
Manteca Bulletin (Calif.), March 2, 2021

Title: Meager water allocations force California farmers to adjust
Description:
California farmers were responding to the meager allocation announcements and were planning accordingly.  In the Huron area, one farmer decided that he will not plant land where he lacks a contract for crops.  A Los Banos area farmer will plant fewer acres of annual crops and enact conservation measures like deficit irrigation of alfalfa and cut wheat early for silage.
AgAlert (Sacramento, Calif.), March 3, 2021

Title: Meager water allocations force California farmers to adjust
Description:

In the Huron area, one farmer decided that he will not plant land where he lacks a contract for crops.  A Los Banos area farmer will plant fewer acres of annual crops and enact conservation measures like deficit irrigation of alfalfa and cut wheat early for silage.
AgAlert (Sacramento, Calif.), March 3, 2021

Description:

AgAlert (Sacramento, Calif.), March 3, 2021

Title: Russian River water pumped into Stafford Lake to bolster supplies as California reservoir remained low
Description:
The North Marin Water District was pumping 600 acre-feet of water from the Russian River into Stafford Lake to increase supplies for the summer, a strategy that was employed by the district during the 1976-77 drought.  The 600 acre-feet amounts to about 30% of the normal demand of the reservoir over the summer.  The district general manager stated that the district intended to fill the lake from 1,300 acre-feet, or 30% capacity, to at least 50% capacity, which will cost about $221,000. 
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), Feb. 27, 2021

Title: Extreme fire behavior in California
Description:
California's 2020 fire season was historic with 9,917 wildfires that charred 4,257,863 acres, per Cal Fire.
USA Today (McLean, Va.), Feb. 3, 2021

More than 4 million acres have burned in California as the state continued to endure massive wildfires, mostly in the northern part of the state.  The amount of land burned is more than twice the previous record area burned during a single year, which occurred in 2018 when blazes charred more than 1.67 million acres.  The August Complex exceeded 1 million acres, another record.
Many dead trees, upwards of 150 million, were killed during the state's recent five-year drought, and were fueling current wildfires.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Oct. 6, 2020

Since the start of 2020, California has endured over 7,900 wildfires that consumed more than 3.6 million acres, according to Cal Fire data.
Desert Sun (Palm Springs, Calif.), Sept. 21, 2020

Drought and heat in California were leading to extreme fire behavior.  Recently numerous fires have grown by tens of thousands of acres in a matter of hours, events that have become more common.  The Creek Fire in Sierra National Forest near Yosemite National Park was one such fire that trapper hundreds of campers who had to be airlifted to safety.  
This far in 2020, California has seen a record 3,900 square miles torched by wildfires as it enters what is typically the height of the fire season.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Sept. 10, 2020

A historically warm, dry February raised the likelihood of a difficult fire season in California.  In Mendocino National Park in northern California, U.S. Forest Service crews were trying to extinguish a blaze burning through timber.  
State firefighters have battled 280 small fires, compared to just 85 by this time last year.  In a rare February event, the U.S. Forest Service put out a fire at the 4,000 level where snow ought to cover the landscape at this time of year.
KRON4 (San Francisco, Calif.), Feb. 26, 2020

California's 2020 fire season was historic with 9,917 wildfires that charred 4,257,863 acres, per Cal Fire.
USA Today (McLean, Va.), Feb. 3, 2021

More than 4 million acres have burned in California as the state continued to endure massive wildfires, mostly in the northern part of the state.  The amount of land burned is more than twice the previous record area burned during a single year, which occurred in 2018 when blazes charred more than 1.67 million acres.  The August Complex exceeded 1 million acres, another record.
Many dead trees, upwards of 150 million, were killed during the state's recent five-year drought, and were fueling current wildfires.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Oct. 6, 2020

Since the start of 2020, California has endured over 7,900 wildfires that consumed more than 3.6 million acres, according to Cal Fire data.
Desert Sun (Palm Springs, Calif.), Sept. 21, 2020

Drought and heat in California were leading to extreme fire behavior.  Recently numerous fires have grown by tens of thousands of acres in a matter of hours, events that have become more common.  The Creek Fire in Sierra National Forest near Yosemite National Park was one such fire that trapper hundreds of campers who had to be airlifted to safety.  
This far in 2020, California has seen a record 3,900 square miles torched by wildfires as it enters what is typically the height of the fire season.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Sept. 10, 2020

A historically warm, dry February raised the likelihood of a difficult fire season in California.  In Mendocino National Park in northern California, U.S. Forest Service crews were trying to extinguish a blaze burning through timber.  
State firefighters have battled 280 small fires, compared to just 85 by this time last year.  In a rare February event, the U.S. Forest Service put out a fire at the 4,000 level where snow ought to cover the landscape at this time of year.
KRON4 (San Francisco, Calif.), Feb. 26, 2020

A historically warm, dry February raised the likelihood of a difficult fire season in California.  In Mendocino National Park in northern California, U.S. Forest Service crews were trying to extinguish a blaze burning through timber.  
State firefighters have battled 280 small fires, compared to just 85 by this time last year.  In a rare February event, the U.S. Forest Service put out a fire at the 4,000 level where snow ought to cover the landscape at this time of year.
KRON4 (San Francisco, Calif.), Feb. 26, 2020

Title: Extreme fire behavior in California
Description:
California's 2020 fire season was historic with 9,917 wildfires that charred 4,257,863 acres, per Cal Fire.
USA Today (McLean, Va.), Feb. 3, 2021

More than 4 million acres have burned in California as the state continued to endure massive wildfires, mostly in the northern part of the state.  The amount of land burned is more than twice the previous record area burned during a single year, which occurred in 2018 when blazes charred more than 1.67 million acres.  The August Complex exceeded 1 million acres, another record.
Many dead trees, upwards of 150 million, were killed during the state's recent five-year drought, and were fueling current wildfires.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Oct. 6, 2020

Since the start of 2020, California has endured over 7,900 wildfires that consumed more than 3.6 million acres, according to Cal Fire data.
Desert Sun (Palm Springs, Calif.), Sept. 21, 2020

Drought and heat in California were leading to extreme fire behavior.  Recently numerous fires have grown by tens of thousands of acres in a matter of hours, events that have become more common.  The Creek Fire in Sierra National Forest near Yosemite National Park was one such fire that trapper hundreds of campers who had to be airlifted to safety.  
This far in 2020, California has seen a record 3,900 square miles torched by wildfires as it enters what is typically the height of the fire season.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Sept. 10, 2020

A historically warm, dry February raised the likelihood of a difficult fire season in California.  In Mendocino National Park in northern California, U.S. Forest Service crews were trying to extinguish a blaze burning through timber.

Since the start of 2020, California has endured over 7,900 wildfires that consumed more than 3.6 million acres, according to Cal Fire data.
Desert Sun (Palm Springs, Calif.), Sept. 21, 2020

Drought and heat in California were leading to extreme fire behavior.  Recently numerous fires have grown by tens of thousands of acres in a matter of hours, events that have become more common.  The Creek Fire in Sierra National Forest near Yosemite National Park was one such fire that trapper hundreds of campers who had to be airlifted to safety.  
This far in 2020, California has seen a record 3,900 square miles torched by wildfires as it enters what is typically the height of the fire season.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Sept. 10, 2020

A historically warm, dry February raised the likelihood of a difficult fire season in California.  In Mendocino National Park in northern California, U.S. Forest Service crews were trying to extinguish a blaze burning through timber.  
State firefighters have battled 280 small fires, compared to just 85 by this time last year.  In a rare February event, the U.S. Forest Service put out a fire at the 4,000 level where snow ought to cover the landscape at this time of year.
KRON4 (San Francisco, Calif.), Feb. 26, 2020

Title: Extreme fire behavior in California
Description:
California's 2020 fire season was historic with 9,917 wildfires that charred 4,257,863 acres, per Cal Fire.
USA Today (McLean, Va.), Feb. 3, 2021

More than 4 million acres have burned in California as the state continued to endure massive wildfires, mostly in the northern part of the state.  The amount of land burned is more than twice the previous record area burned during a single year, which occurred in 2018 when blazes charred more than 1.67 million acres.  The August Complex exceeded 1 million acres, another record.
Many dead trees, upwards of 150 million, were killed during the state's recent five-year drought, and were fueling current wildfires.
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Oct. 6, 2020

Since the start of 2020, California has endured over 7,900 wildfires that consumed more than 3.6 million acres, according to Cal Fire data.

KRON4 (San Francisco, Calif.), Feb. 26, 2020

Title: Dry winter delayed start to irrigation in Fresno County, California
Description:
With the Sierra Nevada snowpack at about 50% of normal, the King’s River Water Association in Fresno County stated that dry conditions will likely leave many farmers drawing more water from underground aquifers.  Irrigation canals would typically be full on March 1, but the dry winter has delayed the start to the irrigation season.  Crops were blooming in the San Joaquin Valley.
KMPH Fox 26 News (Fresno, Calif.), Feb. 22, 2021

Title: Low rainfall has Marin County, California water districts leaning toward mandatory restrictions
Description:
Two water districts in Marin County were considering mandatory water restrictions amid a winter of abnormally low rainfall and the possible return to drought.  The community of Bolinas was also considering mandatory water rationing that could take effect as soon as March 1.  
Much of Marin’s water supply comes from reservoirs replenished with rainwater, but most water agencies have reported less than half of normal rainfall.  
Marin Independent Journal (Calif.), Feb. 9, 2021

The community of Bolinas is on the cusp of mandating water rationing, allowing 150 gallons of water per day.  Bolinas depends on the Arroyo Honda Creek where water levels were far below average.  
North Marin Water’s Stafford reservoir is at 29 percent of capacity, while the district’s seven lakes and reservoirs averaged 57 percent of capacity.  
CBS San Francisco (Calif.), Feb. 9, 2021

Title: Burn permits suspended in two California counties
Description:
Dry conditions and significant fire weather led Cal Fire to suspend all burn permits within the State Responsibility Area and Local Responsibility Areas under contract with Cal Fire in Monterey and San Benito counties effective Jan. 14.  
Since the start of 2021, more than 75 wildfires have burned over 50 acres.  
King City Rustler (Calif.), Jan. 21, 2021

Title: Burn permits suspended in two California counties
Description:
Dry conditions and significant fire weather led Cal Fire to suspend all burn permits within the State Responsibility Area and Local Responsibility Areas under contract with Cal Fire in Monterey and San Benito counties effective Jan. 14.  
Since the start of 2021, more than 75 wildfires have burned over 50 acres.  
King City Rustler (Calif.), Jan. 21, 2021

Title: Permission sought to cut releases from Lake Mendocino in California
Description:
Sonoma Water asked state water regulators for temporary permission to cut releases from Lake Mendocino by half or more under certain conditions to conserve water.  
The Press Democrat (Santa Rosa, Calif.), Jan. 16, 2021

Title: Permission sought to cut releases from Lake Mendocino in California
Description:
Sonoma Water asked state water regulators for temporary permission to cut releases from Lake Mendocino by half or more under certain conditions to conserve water.  
The Press Democrat (Santa Rosa, Calif.), Jan. 16, 2021

Title: Farm ponds low, grass stunted in coastal northern California
Description:
Sonoma County and neighboring area farm ponds were falling and natural springs were drying up, while pasture grass was stunted.  Some operators of organic dairies were concerned about federal mandates on how much time must be spent in pastures to be considered organic.  Some dairies also had to truck in water for the cows.  
The Press Democrat (Santa Rosa, Calif.), Jan. 16, 2021

Title: Farm ponds low, grass stunted in coastal northern California
Description:
Sonoma County and neighboring area farm ponds were falling and natural springs were drying up, while pasture grass was stunted.  Some operators of organic dairies were concerned about federal mandates on how much time must be spent in pastures to be considered organic.  Some dairies also had to truck in water for the cows.  
The Press Democrat (Santa Rosa, Calif.), Jan. 16, 2021

Title: Farm ponds low, grass stunted in coastal northern California
Description:
Sonoma County and neighboring area farm ponds were falling and natural springs were drying up, while pasture grass was stunted.  Some operators of organic dairies were concerned about federal mandates on how much time must be spent in pastures to be considered organic.  Some dairies also had to truck in water for the cows.  
The Press Democrat (Santa Rosa, Calif.), Jan. 16, 2021

Title: Less water flowing into water treatment plant in Santa Rosa, California
Description:
Less water was flowing into Santa Rosa’s water treatment plant where storage ponds typically hold 600 million gallons, but currently held 400 million gallons.  The reduction in stored water means that there will be less recycled water available for agricultural users this spring unless more rain falls.
The Press Democrat (Santa Rosa, Calif.), Jan. 16, 2021

Title: Marin Municipal Water District in California preparing for a dry winter
Description:
The Marin Municipal Water District has been purchasing more imported water earlier than usual from the Sonoma Water in preparation for a dry La Niña winter rather than drawing from its seven reservoirs.  The reservoirs were at 66 percent of capacity at the end of the water year on Sept. 30, which is 96 percent of average capacity for that date.  Water conservation would also be beneficial in stretching the supply.
The Mercury News (Calif.), Oct. 10, 2020

Title: Marin Municipal Water District in California preparing for a dry winter
Description:
The Marin Municipal Water District has been purchasing more imported water earlier than usual from the Sonoma Water in preparation for a dry La Niña winter rather than drawing from its seven reservoirs.  The reservoirs were at 66 percent of capacity at the end of the water year on Sept. 30, which is 96 percent of average capacity for that date.  Water conservation would also be beneficial in stretching the supply.
The Mercury News (Calif.), Oct. 10, 2020

Title: More funds for Klamath Reclamation Project in Oregon
Description:
The U.S. House of Representatives passed an amendment of the 2000 Klamath Basin Water Supply Enhancement Act, which will better distribute $10 million in funding annually to drought relief efforts in the Klamath Basin.
Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), Oct. 1, 2020

Title: More funds for Klamath Reclamation Project in Oregon
Description:
The U.S. House of Representatives passed an amendment of the 2000 Klamath Basin Water Supply Enhancement Act, which will better distribute $10 million in funding annually to drought relief efforts in the Klamath Basin.
Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), Oct. 1, 2020

Title: Drought, heat affected grape growth in Napa County, California
Description:
A grape grower in Carneros reported vines struggling, due to dry soils, and reduced yields.  Chardonnay yields were down over 50 percent and Pinot Noir grapes were at least 15 percent below average.  
Napa Valley Register (Calif.), Aug. 25, 2020

Title: Boat ramps closed at Lake Mendocino in California
Description:
The low level of Lake Mendocino has resulted in several boats running aground as the Lake Mendocino basin endured its third driest year on record, following 1977 and 1924.  The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers closed the north boat ramp on Aug. 9 and closed the south boat ramp on Aug. 18, preventing the launching of large vessels in the lake.
Water releases into the Russian River continued at 165 cubic feet per second to comply with minimum in-stream flows for fish.  The lake level was dropping by about one foot and 300 acre-feet of volume daily, which is not uncommon for the end of summer, according to the chief operations manager at the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers.
The Mendocino Voice (Ukiah, Calif.), Aug. 21, 2020

Title: Water diverted into Lower Klamath Project to aid breeding birds in southern Oregon, northern California
Description:
Klamath Project wetlands were low on water since fall 2019 and needed additional water in July 2020 to maintain habitat for breeding birds on Lower Klamath and suckers in Tule Lake.  The Bureau of Reclamation began diverting 30 cubic feet per second of water into Lower Klamath Refuge on July 15 and began diverting 100 cfs into Tule Lake around Aug. 10.  Water was freed up by compensating farmers and ranchers for voluntarily idling land or relying on groundwater irrigation.  
The influx of water also stemmed a particularly bad botulism outbreak at the Lower Klamath refuge in mid-July.
Klamath Falls Herald and News (Ore.), Aug. 25, 2020

Title: Water diverted into Lower Klamath Project to aid breeding birds in southern Oregon, northern California
Description:
Klamath Project wetlands were low on water since fall 2019 and needed additional water in July 2020 to maintain habitat for breeding birds on Lower Klamath and suckers in Tule Lake.  The Bureau of Reclamation began diverting 30 cubic feet per second of water into Lower Klamath Refuge on July 15 and began diverting 100 cfs into Tule Lake around Aug. 10. Title: Hundreds of wildfires burning in California
Description:
Amid a historic fire season, California has had more acres burn in 2020 than in most other years and the active fall fire season is yet to come.  As 7,002 fires charred the landscape, more than 1.4 million acres have burned, compared to 2019 when 4,292 fires consumed 56,000 acres by this time.
The Golden State’s second and third largest fires ever were currently burning.  The LNU Lightning Complex near Vacaville was the second largest fire at 350,030 acres and was 22 percent contained.  The third largest, the SCU Lightning Complex in the South and East Bay, were 10 percent contained at 347,196 acres.
Statewide, 625 individual fires were burning.
The Mercury News (San Jose, Calif.), Aug 25, 2020

California wildfires have burned more than 1.2 million acres, or 1,875 square miles, through Aug. 24, according to Daniel Berlant, assistant deputy director with Cal Fire.  The state endured more than 13,000 lightning strikes, igniting more than 600 wildfires since Aug. 15.  
ABC News (New York), Aug. 24, 2020

More than 360 wildfires were burning across California as the parched state entered its second week of a heatwave, with many of those blazes moving through areas of brushland, rural spaces, canyons and dense forest to the north, east and south of San Francisco.  At least three people lost their lives.  More than 60,000 people were evacuated from their homes as fires charred roughly 780 square miles.  
On Aug. 18, Gov. Gavin Newsom declared a state of emergency for the Golden State to make available resources for fighting the wave of fires, many of them sparked by lightning. Most of California was abnormally dry or in drought.
Las Vegas Sun (Nev.), Aug. 21, 2020
